Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Development of a Micropost Approach for the Contractile Maturation of iPS-Derived Cardiomyocytes

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Sniadecki, Nathan J.
Proposal Number: 1509106

The goal of this project is to develop a novel strategy that improves the functionality of cardiomyocytes derived from human induced pluripotent stem cells (hiPSC-CMs) in culture. Human induced pluripotent stem cells are not harvested from embryos, which means they can serve as a noncontroversial and plentiful source of cardiomyocytes. These cells have the potential to be used to reverse the damage to cardiac tissue caused by heart attacks, assess new pharmacological treatments for heart disease, and serve as a model system for studying heart development. To unlock the potential of hiPSC-CMs, this project will evaluate the effects of mechanical cues like substrate stiffness, cell shape, cyclic strain, and cell-cell contact in combination with biochemical treatments that promote cardiac maturation. The expected outcome of this project is an effective approach for in vitro culture of hiPSC-CMs that can be widely adopted.

The lack the contractile power and maturation markers for hiPSC-CMs is a major challenge to overcome in order for these cells to be used effectively as a source of new cardiomyocytes. To address this challenge, the efforts in this project are centered on using arrays of flexible microposts for evaluating the contractile forces of hiPSC-CMs and quantitative fluorescence microscopy techniques to assess their myofibril structure, hypertrophy, isoform expression, and calcium handling. Tasks 1 and 2 of this project focus on studying the mechanical cues that improve the contractility and maturation of hiPSC-CMs, including cell alignment, cell-cell contact, extracellular stiffness, and applied strain. Task 3 examines the effectiveness of these mechanical cues alongside biochemical treatments that are related to cardiac development. The broader impacts of this work lie in the potential advancement of new cardiac therapies, drug screening, and developmental studies. In addition, the project has educational and outreach components that will impact the training and career development of future engineers who will work at the interface between engineering, cardiology, and developmental biology.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to develop a new approach to assess the contractility of cardiomyocytes derived from human induced pluripotent stem cells (hiPSC-CMs). There is high potential in the use of hiPSC-CMs for regenerating the heart, identifying promising new medical drugs, or studying the underlying causes and characteristics of genetic heart diseases. However, one shortcoming with hiPSC-CMs is that they lack the contractile power and structural machinery found in adult cardiomyocytes. For hiPSC-CM to reach their potential, we need to identify protocols and approaches that mature these cells to a stage that resembles their adult counterparts. Thus, in this project we aimed to study the role of mechanical cues that can improve the maturation of hiPSC-CMs. These mechanical cues were investigated alongside biochemical treatments that are related to cardiac development to improve hiPSC-CM contractile performance.

 

To address the intellectual merit of this project, we utilized flexible silicone substrates that have been engineered to measure the contractile force of hiPSC-CMs. Specifically, we used these substrates to evaluate our maturation approaches by using contractile force as a functional readout. In our main efforts, we used arrays of silicone microposts on which hiPSC-CMs were grown with standard tissue culture protocols. The dimensions of the microposts were microscale and arrayed closely together in a vertical orientation so that hiPSC-CMs were able to attach and lie across the tips of the microposts but not squeeze in between the microposts. As hiPSC-CMs generated their contractile forces, they caused the silicone posts to bend like a cantilevered beam. From tracking the amount of deflection caused by the hiPSC-CMs, we were able to calculate the amount of force they produce in nanonewtons. Using our micropost arrays, we evaluated the effect of thyroid hormone treatment and microRNA overexpression on the maturation of hiPSC-CMs. In addition, we used the micropost arrays as a functional assay for hiPSC-CMs derived from patients with genetic cardiomyopathies. In one corollary effort, we used a two-post approach with tissue engineered constructs made from hiPSC-CMs to measure their contractile performance in a 3D environment that promoted their maturation. In a second corollary effort, we used 2D silicone substrates made from a formulation of silicone that is highly compliant. By engineering the stiffness and adhesivity of this material, we were able to control the mechanical cues that influence hiPSC-CM maturation. We found that there was an ideal combination of mechanical cues that promoted hiPSC-CM maturation based on the flexibility to the silicone substrate, the elongate shape that the hiPSC-CMs were allowed to adopt, and the promotion of cell-to-cell contact by increased seeding density. The outcomes of this project has led to novel technologies, several journal publications, a patent, and improved knowledge on the mechanobiology of hiPSC-CMs.

 

The broader impacts of this project had wide reaching contributions to multiple research fields and in training new engineers and scientists. Specifically, a better understanding of how genetic mutation lead to cardiac diseases can be studied at the cellular level with patient-derived induced pluripotent stem cells. The work generated a greater understanding of the relationship between mechanical cues and cardiomyocyte maturation by developing a novel means of control substrate stiffness, cell shape, and cell-cell contact. In this project, there was an emphasis on the training of future generations in cellular biomechanics and advanced biomaterials by involving postdoctoral trainees, graduate students, and undergraduate students in the research. Lastly, the project had impact in engineering education and outreach efforts through participation in several events each year.  

 


Last Modified: 09/26/2019
Modified by: Nathan J Sniadecki
